"What do you mean by 'more honorable'? I don't understand those words to describe what people do. 'More honorable,' 'nobler'—those are old ideas that I don't agree with. Anything that helps people is honorable. I only understand one word: useful! You can laugh all you want, but that's true!"

Pyotr Petrovitch laughed loudly. He had finished counting the money and was putting it away, but he left some of the bills on the table. The 'cesspool question' had already caused arguments between them. It was strange that it made Lebeziatnikov really angry, while it amused Luzhin, who wanted to annoy his young friend at that moment.

"You're in a bad mood today because of your bad luck yesterday," Lebeziatnikov said, even though he still respected Pyotr Petrovitch and didn't dare to argue with him.

"You should tell me this," Pyotr Petrovitch interrupted with a proud tone, "are you friendly enough with that young woman to ask her to come in here for a minute? I think they’ve all come back from the cemetery... I heard footsteps... I want to see her."

"Why?" Lebeziatnikov asked, surprised.

"Oh, I want to. I'm leaving here today or tomorrow, and I want to talk to her about... Well, you can be there during the talk. It's better that you are, actually. You never know what might happen."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pyotr Petrovitch expresses disdain for traditional notions of honor, emphasizing that only usefulness defines human activity.
